ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a ton about microeconomics. Lots of applications of multivariable calculus.
I practiced doing math problems...
Expanded on material from intro micro economics.
LaGrange... so much Lagrange.
problem solving in economics
Deeper mathematical understanding of the concepts taught in the intro microeconomic course.

A better understanding of microeconomics on the whole: maximization problems with LaGrangian multipliers, risk, trade and production, game theory and oligopoly. It was a good refresher course after taking Math 120 during my first semester at Yale, and was useful in other classes that required a similar level of math/micro knowledge.
How to use math (mostly Lagrange and derivatives) in economic problems.

In this class, I deepened the understanding of the topics that I learned in introductory microeconomics by expanding the analytical tools available to solve more complex optimization problems. We applied this knowledge to topics such as consumer utility, exchange economies, risk, and competition in markets.
I learned about both the fundamentals and the details of Microeconomics, including utility maximization, cost minimization, and much more.
Learned lots of different models for understanding microeconomics.

Great building off of intro microeconomics! From consumer demand to competitive equilibrium to monopolies to Cournot competition to collusion to risk and insurance, we learned about many econ concepts and their real world applications.
A calculus based approach to microeconomics

Knowledge of a wide range of topics, results, and core ideas of microeconomics including (among others): Consumer preferences, deriving consumer demand functions under a variety of conditions, inter-temporal decision making, labor markets, substitution/income effects, welfare theorems, risk-adversity, how prices are set in competition, oligopolies, and monopolies.
Also gained skills in applying some mathematical tools to solve problems in microeconomics (hint, lots of lagrange multipliers!).
In general just gained lots of intuition and skills for thinking more quantitatively and in a more nuanced way about a wide range microeconomic questions.
I learned about basic microeconomic theory, including consumer choices, risk, perfect competition, monopolies, and oligopolies.

- Consumption Theory
- Production Theory
- Slutsky Equation and different effects (income vs substitution)
- Effects of taxes, subsidies, etc.
I learned a lot about how to approach pricing and consumer and producer problems.
elementary calculus and linear algebra
combining calculus with microeconomic theory
microeconomic theory; consumer/firm theory; lagrangian method
I learned higher level microeconomic concepts and many mathematical approaches to economic models
Max firms profits and utilities, risk, game theory
General econ intuition
Good standard intermediate microeconomics course. Eva does a great job making the sometimes bland learning material interesting.
A lot of math, economic theories
I developed more advanced microeconomics skills. I was able to apply basic introduction skills and use them to learn new techniques.
Intermediate economics built QR skills and economic tools.
I developed more in depth knowledge about microeconomics, including game theory, monopolies, Hessian matrices, and trade in supply and demand. I was able to apply calculus to these topics.
Lagrange and maximization
Economic concepts along with their mathematical foundations
Knowledge on microeconomic theories and applying mathematical concepts to these theories
I learned a lot about microeconomic theory and the forces that influence how people make decisions. From monopolies to Nash Equilibrium, we covered a broad range of material.
- strong quantitative skills
mathematical models and applications of microeconomics

This class, as the name suggests, teaches the fundamentals of microeconomics, and dives deeper through the use of partial derivatives. This allows for a greater intuition to be developed with the content learned in Introductory Microeconomics. One skill heavily emphasized is Lagrange, as well as several other skills important for any course, such as time management, how to study effectively, etc.
Learned more about the fundamentals of Econ
good intermediate level econ
I learned how to apply Lagrangian optimization to various economic concepts
deeper understanding of macroeconomic models in various applications ( risk, insurance, intertemporal decisions, game theory, firms )
A general elaboration on concepts covered in intro micro along with more calculus.
An understanding of the mathematics behind game theory, perfect complements/substitutes, monopoly, perfect competition, etc.
This course is super important for me to build a solid foundation for resource economics. The Lagrange multiplier, first order and second order conditions are very important.
Strong microeconomic foundations.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A wonderful, engaging professor. It would be great if midterms were actually designed for the allotted time we have.
Don't think there are any glaring weaknesses. I absolutely loved Professor Chalioti. She was a huge strength in the course.
Strengths: Professor Chalioti is very kind + enthusiastic, and the course is very well-organized. Weaknesses: Just very boring material - I supposed this can't be helped.

Strengths: Professor and staff were great, office hours were incredibly helpful
Weaknesses: Some material felt a bit rushed and their weren't that many exercises to practice with for exams

Professor is passionate and really good at explaining the concepts. She does her best to make the really mathematical content of the course connect to real-world economics and the significance of what we're learning. 

However, it is still an entire course just full of Lagrange and math... 
Also, would prefer some cleaner numbers on the PSET.

The professor is very understanding and goes out of the way to make this semester's circumstances easier on the students. I also like that she both goes through lecture and does problems in class; many of my previous economics core courses did not do so many examples in class; they were only part of the PowerPoints. On the downside, I wish we could have gotten previous exams to study from; the problem sets are great study tools, but I think many students also wanted to see old content and study based off of those.

The psets were excessively hard, but that was to be expected 

Professor Chalioti is great at reviewing the topics covered in the class

Strengths: Professor Chalioti is kind and caring about her students, and wants to make sure that we come away with a greater appreciation for microeconomics. Tests are fair, and problem sets are useful to prepare. 

Weaknesses: The class should put a greater emphasis on the Ed discussion forum, since those forums tend to be a more lively place to ask questions. Many students were also confused about the content in the second half of the course (trade, supply, production), mainly because there were several lectures in succession in which it was unclear when to use certain approaches, and when to use others.

Generally, the class is just a lot of math, and sometimes, the problems seem needlessly complex from an algebraic standpoint. There should be practice exams available to students beyond what is available for the discussion sections.
Difficult material, great professor.
This course does a good job of building upon the topics covered in Introductory Microeconomics, although the podcasts did not do too much to increase my understanding of the topics.

Strength: Structured lectures, loved that the professor reviewed content from previous lectures to set up for the current and future lectures.
Weakness: Sections could be improved to be more helpful. They felt rushed.
Sometimes too much content in lecture rushing through slides and hard to follow.
I really liked the real world applications! Wording/clarity of some pset questions could be improved.

Strengths: the sections do a great job of reinforcing learning
Weaknesses: There's SO much material and I was upset that the final wasn't open book; even though I didn't need my notes in the final, I just would've been a lot less stressed preparing for it

Strengths: 
Covered lots of interesting material, touching on central ideas on a variety of things. Very clear lectures, both in terms of conceptual presentation as well as working through problems. PSETS extended and practiced skills gained in lecture, and solutions posted which helped clarify any questions which might have existed. Grading was fair.

Weaknesses:
Occasionally (though I think others exaggerate this point), felt like problems just required doing lots of algebra and relatively little intellectual engagement. Sometimes it felt like we covered things too superficially to really understand what was deeply going on, though there is some trade-off on this issue with how mathematically sophisticated the class is meant to be. Sometimes felt like material jumped around a little bit from topic to topic, though maybe this is a necessary feature of such a wide-ranging course. Lastly, since it is such a big lecture you don't get much personal feedback, but not much can be done to improve this point.

Strengths: The material was presented in an engaging fashion (through powerpoint but also live "problem-solving" through an iPad) 

Weaknesses: The course covered mainly the same principles as Econ 115 (Introductory microeconomics), although at a more rigorous level (with calculus). However, I would have liked to learn more about the applications of some of these concepts in the real world, as well as go into more depth with some of these theories.

Strengths:
- Clear content that is structured
- office hours phenomenal
- lectures were clear

Weaknesses:
- Plug and chug, easy to get lost there instead of why it matters
Section could be more engaging.

Though the professor does a good job of explaining why economics are interesting, and does a good job of explaining the material, I think more could be done to explicitly demonstrate how the theoretical material is backed up by real-world data.

strengths- eva is a great prof; very knowledgeable and understanding
weaknesses- if you don't like econ this is an agonizing class
Overall a very great course. The professor is excellent.
This course is extremely math-heavy with very little effort dedicated to testing and/or teaching the conceptual nature of the content.

Strengths: very organized, material builds on each other, very interesting
Weaknesses: at times dense and overwhelming, felt like we couldn't spend too long on any one concept
Best teacher.

I found the professors style of showing example problems in class to be difficult to follow, as they often ended up in pages that were long and confusing to follow, which then made looking back at them and using them to study very difficult.
Just more practice problems would be helpful
Ample office hours and peer support

I felt like I was stronger with monopolies, but struggled with economies with production. To improve, I could look online for extra resources as well as join office hours and reach out to professors for help.

Strengths: Many resources, well taught
Weaknesses: Easy to lose focus

I think one weakness was that the information on the psets was only covered in section and we did not really go over it in class. A strength is the office hours and the examples that we do do in class.
There was almost no review material given for midterm and exams. Often concepts not taught in lecture or section would be asked in exams and in problem sets which wasnt ideal.
I think lectures were clear and the was a lot of extra help outside class which was good

strengths: good progression through the topics, problem sets coincided well with the material, I learned effectively
weaknesses: the second half of the course felt a bit more scattered than the first half. I felt like I had a weaker grip on the material after the midterm than before it.
Very engaging material

One strength of the course was the enthusiasm of the TFs and the professor. However, the course moved very fast and the psets were very time consuming considering the relatively small percentage of our final grade that they made up
Not very organized, difficult to follow.

One of the biggest strengths of this course is the way it is taught, both through lectures, discussion sections, and problem sets. The lectures allow the students to learn the theory and start to understand the mathematics behind solving problems, while the discussion sections review the more challenging problems with interesting / unique solutions, and the problem sets cement the students' understanding of the topics.

However, this course did have one notable weakness: its lack of practice problems. I noted that the exams were difficult, not due to their inherent content but due to the lack of practice problems provided to review for the exams. While there were some problems provided, I wish there just were a larger number of problems given to practice with.
Could have given better info during the lectures.

Strengths: super well organized, clear psets
Weaknesses: some psets were way longer than others?

Strengths: Professor Chalioti cares a lot about students and keeps the class engaging 

Weaknesses: The class was too theoretical at times but mostly because of the nature of the material
clear delivery by instructor, organized and well-paced psets and exams
One of the biggest strengths of this course is that the professor works through problems in class, which is very helpful to understanding the material and thinking through the math.

Strengths: Eva is a great professor who is really invested in student's learning. She has super clear lectures and is very available to chat with. Her exams are also pretty fair and don't try to trick you like other econ classes.

Weaknesses: Not many, beyond the fact that the content is not super interesting or relevant to the real world. Required for the major.
The class in general was pretty interesting, just complex concepts behind it.

I guess Prof. and instructors (and even IT support) did their best to cater to the needs of students at this critical juncture. So, I do not see any weaknesses. But, international students might need a bit more concern at this critical time.

Professor Chalioti is such a nice professor who really does enjoy teaching the class. She made sure to make everything super fun. The class would have benefitted from more practice materials. There def was not enough in my opinion, like no practice exams from past semesters were given out.
Strengths: Psets were very comprehensive, professor explanations were very clear.

Strength: 
1. The instructor was organized, well prepared, and used class time efficiently.
2. The instructor effectively explained and illustrated course concepts (e.g. using lecture notes).
3. The course was organized in a manner that helped me understand underlying concepts.
4.The assigned readings helped me understand the course material.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Everything COVID-19 related went well. I just want in-person classes.
I think the grading policy definitely succeeded as it made the course a lot less stressful during such a difficult time.

recorded lectures and sections; it was great to have something to go back to during studying. Rewatching lectures was very helpful in my studying, and in previous years, if we were assigned to a not-so-effective section, we would have a hard time keeping up with kids with better TAs; now I can go and watch many different sections from the same week and learn a topic from different perspectives/different explanations. I know a lot of other students also cross-watched sections, and it was great to have all the TAs and a resource that way instead of just one.
The extensive availability of office hours and peer tutor hours was very useful.
Professor Chalioti is good at managing the Zoom classroom
I think the abundance of TA's and office hours made getting help for the course very accessible. One thing I did not enjoy was the podcasts, which didn't really deepen my understanding of the topics.
Synchronous lectures worked well.
Sections offered great interaction in a smaller setting.

Success: recordings, I needed those...
Improve: so very hard to focus on just straight up math for an hour and fifteen minutes over zoom
The live lectures, along with the discussion sections were great for facilitating learning. In addition, Professor Chalioti had review sessions before each exam, which were very helpful.
the recorded lectures helped a lot with some of the more complicated material
Recorded lectures were really helpful.
the live virtual lecture format is the best for this kind of a class
Nothing much

Succeeded: in-lecture ipad math problems, recorded lectures to refer back to, recorded discussion sections to refer back to
Improved: could have done polls - might have  been fun
Loved this class.

I didnt find that the course leaders made any enough changes to the class policies given the pandemic, and given how difficult this semester was in general for online learning, I felt that more should have been done to aid students and make it easier for them to want to continue engaging with the course.
Recording lectures was great so we could go back and rewatch

I felt like the style of class was organized the best it could be given the circumstances. The professors did a good job teaching material and giving us opportunities to learn. I wish there had been more polls or something to be more engaging.
Online format was fine.
I think the practices geared toward the pandemic all succeeded, especially the lecture format.
I thought the class was well conducted under these circumstances
The iPad served as an effective substitute to the blackboard. Zoom classes were not ideal, but given the circumstances, were a fair alternative.
- very engaging office hours
live zoom lecture (also recorded) worked well, because we could ask questions to the professor in class in the chat but also rewatch the lectures later to review difficult concepts
Not much could be changed.
The recorded lectures were great as well as the sections

The recorded lectures were a helpful option that really helped me go back and re-learn concepts and work on a pace that made sense with my schedule. I would love it if recorded lectures were posted even after the pandemic. Something that was difficult was finding people to do problem sets with since everything is virtual; hard to make new friends.
I guess the course was pretty successful in providing the best knowledge and skill.
Lectures were very engaging and there were many Zoom office hours.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yeah! The course is super interesting, although I assume you are only taking this for a requirement for a major. Definitely take with Professor Chalioti though, she is an absolute gem and one of the best professors I have ever had at Yale.

Not unless you need it for Econ/Global/EPE etc. You basically just practice doing calculus/algebra, I don't feel like I learned any more economics than I did in intro micro, but it was still stressful since exams are a time-crunch and psets often have long math problems to trudge through. I'd say it's low intellectual challenge but high workload. That said, the Professor (Eva) is so sweet and enthusiastic, the TFs are great, and overall the course was very well-organized.
Kinda, I only took the course because it was required for my major. If you are not taking the course as a pre-req, I would recommend you just take intro-micro instead.
Only take the course if you need it as a requirement, or for future courses that require this as a requirement.
Sure for completing your major requirements

Most people take the class because they have to, but if you really like math and economics, you could have fun in this class.

It is A LOT of math, though, so if you don't like math and don't need this class, maybe take something else.

The class does have good applications if you're looking to take other classes in the department, like climate change economics with Nordhaus, for example.

Yes if you need to. Otherwise, probably not. If you took high school econ and are debating between this and 115, take this!! This class was very much a repeat of ECON 115 with an emphasis on mathematical techniques (mainly LaGrange) to build upon the ideas introduced in 115. If you have the sufficient math background for it ie. a decent grasp on calc and know/are willing to self study LaGrange and partial derivatives, take this over 115! Chalioti is not the most engaging lecturer and sometimes the material can feel muddled. The problem sets can also be annoying since they will often involve tedious math with not clean solutions that you sometimes need a calculator for so I wish the numbers were nicer so that it was more conducive to learning the material
If you have just taken intro to micro and were very excited by the topics, I would recommend you take this class to deepen your understanding and expand your economic toolkit.
Only if they are an economics major.
Pretty tough course but helpful and necessary for economics degree
Yes, a great course for the Econ or CSEC major!
Required for econ but also some topics were really cool; I really liked game theory and I also liked thinking from the firm's perspective

Yes. This covers a wide variety of interesting and applicable microeconomics questions, and also provides a foundational set of concepts and tools which can be used in future classes or just in your thinking in general. Prof. Chaltioti is a very clear lecturer, and although the math can get tedious that is how you derive the results, and practice makes perfect, so you get better by doing it.
Yes, only if you are considering the Econ major. Otherwise, it is basically a repeat of Econ 115, but with calculus.
Yes!
Honestly, only if its required.
Nah. You get all of the conceptual stuff from Intro Micro - this is teaching you very effete forms of microeconomic theory that don't seem too useful.

no. if you're not an econ major (or end up deciding that you're not going to be an econ major before the withdrawal deadline) don't take it or drop it. if you need it as a pre-req and can take it credit/d/fail, credit/d/fail it. if you need it, good luck charlie.
Sure, esp as an EP&E major (this course is a requirement)
I would recommend this course to another student - the professor is great
Yes, the teacher was amazing.
With Eva yes. With someone else.... try to think if it's possible to restructure your classes so that you take it with Eva later
I would only recommend this course to students who must take it to fulfill the Economics major.
Only take this if youre an Econ major. There is really no reason to do so otherwise. Content is dry and exams are notoriously hard
If you need to take intermediate microeconomics for your major, then try to take the class with Eva!
Requirement
Yes. It gave me necessary skills to proceed with similar classes in economics.
I would only recommend to an economics major.

If you are taking this class, you are probably an economics or associated major so you have to take this class. However, it is a good class to explore microeconomics more in depth and it also unlocks a lot more economics electives.
Take it for your major
Only if they need it for their major.
I would. It was a challenging class, but I learned a lot about the forces that govern our everyday interactions.
Yes

Yes, if you are interested in the subject.  Although you learn more than you learned in intro micro, a lot of the models are still generalized past the point of being realistic which can be frustrating.  So worth taking if you need it for your major, but if you just want to know some econ, intro micro is enough.

if you are really interested in the more mathematical modeling side of microeconomics! I took this as a non-major and ended up credit/d-ing it because I was having trouble keeping up, but the material was very interesting
Well, if you need it as a requirement, you need to take it.

Yes, I would recommend this course to any student that has taken ECON 115 or equivalent, as it builds on the knowledge of introductory microeconomics and strengthens one's math skills. It offers an interesting approach to many topics, and provides better context (with mathematics) and intuition for the relationships between different economic theories and concepts.
Yes. You need it for the Econ major and teaches you insightful info
not unless you need it for the major
If required for major yes or if interested in more about Econ. This class is very challenging and needs utmost interest/engagement to succeed.
yes. its a great class and take it with professor Chailoti!

You probably need this class for your major if you're taking it (Global Affairs, Econ, or EPE) so I would say yes amongst all of the choices to fulfill this requirement. Definitely take this class with Eva as she is such a sweetheart and always full of energy and enthusiasm. I'll also add that you don't need a strong math background to do well in this class  I only took Math 112 and while I found the course difficult, it wasn't due to the calculus but rather the broader methods in general. The only calculus we use is derivatives (total and partial derivatives) and the langrange multiplier, all of which we learn in class and are pretty straightforward.
Yes, I do recommend this course to another student, especially for resource economics. I belong to Yale School of the Environment with focus on forest economics.
Yea if you are good at and enjoy math you should take it.
Yes, especially with Eva Chalioti.
Yes. It is the one of the best ECON courses.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live section (it was also recorded)
We had virtual discussion sessions as well
recorded lecture, live virtual lecture
live virtual lecture
Occasionally recorded lecture
NA
Office hours, podcasts
None.
Discussion section
We also had virtual small group sections to work through practice exercises of class material.
Recordings of both section and lecture were available
Also had once weekly virtual sections with a TF.
Discussion Sections
- Weekly section, highly recommended
n/a
only live virtual lecture
NA
Livr virtual lecture with recordings plus live section
Recorded lecture, live discussion sections
Watched asynchronously.
Lectures were recorded as well
Lecture and weekly section
Weekly discussion section
Recorded lectures
None
Live virtual lecture that was also recorded.
Lectures were recorded
live virtual lecture and virtual discussion section
live zoom lectures and weekly discussion sections, lectures also recorded
Na
discussion section, virtual
Section once a week
It was technically live, but I often watched the recorded version.
Lectures were recorded
Same as above
None
